Award.AwardTitle: Reactions of Folded Molecules in Water
Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of processes that take place in the chemical industry use organic solvents, solvents that are generally obtained from petrochemicals. Adapting these processes to the "greenest" solvent - water - remains a challenge. This project to be conducted by Professor Julius Rebek at The Scripps Research Institute uses synthetic, container-shape, molecules for reactions in water. The "containers" act as nanovessels that show robust stability and can be used and re-used over a wide range of conditions. A broader impact of this research is the benefit of developing sustainable chemistry. Another impact is the discovery of new molecules for use in water-proof coatings and nanomachines. Postdoctoral researchers benefit from learning how research projects translate from chemical discovery to applications in new materials.

The chemistry of molecules confined to small containers - nanoscale compounds known as cavitands - is a relatively new undertaking. This research takes advantage of an early discovery that long-chain organic compounds assume unusual, folded shapes within the cavitand's space. The folded shapes, induced by hydrophobic forces, push the substrate's ends together and promote large-ring cyclization processes. The cavitands act as templates. Folding also blocks some sites on the chain and exposes others to reactions with agents in the aqueous medium. The blocking action promises new chemical pathways for remote carbon-hydrogen activation in functionalization reactions that typically lead to 5 or 6-membered ring sizes. Functional groups that are remote in extended molecules are brought into proximity when folded in cavitands. The functions no longer act independently and can affect each other's reactivity; showing the consequences of this "entanglement" is one of the basic science novelties expected from this research. The practical consequences may include synthetic methods for access to molecules that cannot be made by conventional means.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Currently, the majority of chemical reactions performed in industry take place in organic solvents, solvents that are generally obtained from petrochemicals. This research showed how those reactions could take place in the greenest of solvents, water. The research created new water-soluble synthetic containers that have cavities of varying sizes and shapes. The containers can act as sensors, isolation chambers and reaction vessels.

One example is a container molecule that can separate fractions of petroleum distillates under mild, energy efficient conditions. This container molecule allows the isolation of p-xylene from its isomers, in a sustainable way that recycles the containers. The p-xylene is used in the large-scale synthesis of common polymers.

The small molecules inside the container compounds are often held in unusual shapes that favor reactions that are improbable in bulk solution. Long-chain compounds are bound inside the containers in folded shapes that bring the molecule's ends closer together. These folded shapes are favorable for reactions that make large ring products-macrocycles. A number of different reactions of confined molecules were successfully conducted over the course of the grant. These include aldol reactions of long-chain aldehydes that allowed the synthesis of new compounds that cannot be prepared by usual methods in water.

The confinement in the containers was also used to tame the behavior of otherwise reactive species known as radicals. The radicals were generated in the containers where they could be reduced efficiently and in a controlled manner by conventional reagents. 

The behavior of molecules in synthetic containers is quite different than that of molecules free in solution. The containers offer insights to the environment experienced by molecules in the confined spaces of the enzymes and receptors found in Nature.


Last Modified: 05/21/2021
Modified by: Julius Rebek
